articles.headline: One Execution Botched, Oklahoma Delays the Next
articles.snippet: An inmate’s execution was stayed after another condemned man, Clayton D. Lockett, died in what witnesses said was an agonizing scene: He writhed and said, “Oh, man,” after being declared unconscious.
articles.abstract: An inmate’s execution was stayed after another condemned man, Clayton D. Lockett, died in what witnesses said was an agonizing scene: He writhed and said, “Oh, man,” after being declared unconscious.
articles.lead_paragraph: McALESTER, Okla. — What was supposed to be the first of two executions here on Tuesday night was halted when the prisoner, Clayton D. Lockett, began to writhe and gasp after he had already been declared unconscious and called out “oh, man,” according to witnesses.

articles.headline: Revenue Up at Twitter, but Growth Is a Worry
articles.snippet: Twitter said that it had more than doubled revenues, but its stock fell more than 11 percent in after-hours trading because the number of people who joined it did not increase as fast as many had hoped.
articles.abstract: Twitter said that it had more than doubled revenues, but its stock fell more than 11 percent in after-hours trading because the number of people who joined it did not increase as fast as many had hoped.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Twitter is struggling to convince Wall Street that it is still a company with plenty of potential to grow.

articles.headline: The Rise of the Drone Master: Pop Culture Recasts Obama
articles.snippet: Drone strikes and government eavesdropping have become themes for movies like “Captain America: The Winter Soldier,” as well as for art exhibitions.
articles.abstract: Drone strikes and government eavesdropping have become themes for movies like “Captain America: The Winter Soldier,” as well as for art exhibitions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In Marvel’s latest popcorn thriller, Captain America battles Hydra, a malevolent organization that has infiltrated the highest levels of the United States government. There are missile attacks, screeching car chases, enormous explosions, evil assassins, data-mining supercomputers and giant killer drones ready to obliterate millions of people.

articles.headline: Two Giant Banks, Seen as Immune, Become Targets
articles.snippet: Prosecutors, in seeking guilty pleas from Credit Suisse and BNP Paribas, are looking to address public outrage and alter the belief that Wall Street institutions are “too big to jail.”
articles.abstract: Prosecutors, in seeking guilty pleas from Credit Suisse and BNP Paribas, are looking to address public outrage and alter the belief that Wall Street institutions are “too big to jail.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors are nearing criminal charges against some of the world’s biggest banks, according to lawyers briefed on the matter, a development that could produce the first guilty plea from a major bank in more than two decades.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: In the U.S., Punishment Comes Before the Crimes
articles.snippet: In 2012, 2.2 million Americans were in jail or prison, a larger share of the population than in any other country.
articles.abstract: In 2012, 2.2 million Americans were in jail or prison, a larger share of the population than in any other country.
articles.lead_paragraph: Few things are better at conveying what a nation really cares than how it spends its money. On that measure, Americans like to punish.

articles.headline: Slow Going on Overhaul of Mortgage Finance
articles.snippet: The Senate Banking Committee is drafting a bill that would dismantle Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac and create a federal regulator called the Federal Mortgage Insurance Corporation.
articles.abstract: The Senate Banking Committee is drafting a bill that would dismantle Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac and create a federal regulator called the Federal Mortgage Insurance Corporation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the long, boggy work of overhauling the nation’s mortgage finance system, Tuesday morning was supposed to be an important milestone: the Senate Banking Committee was scheduled to meet and put the finishing touches on a bipartisan bill that would affect the ability of millions of Americans to buy a home.

articles.headline: Allstate Case Shows Risk of Signing Away the Right to Sue
articles.snippet: A group of former Allstate agents are looking for their day in court after waiving their right to bring a lawsuit. They said they had no choice but to sign.
articles.abstract: A group of former Allstate agents are looking for their day in court after waiving their right to bring a lawsuit. They said they had no choice but to sign.
articles.lead_paragraph: When his children were young, Nathan Littlejohn was a regional salesman in search of a position that would allow him to spend more time with his family. So when he heard about Allstate’s neighborhood agent program in 1990, he was intrigued.

articles.headline: Ukraine Says That Militants Won the East
articles.snippet: Ukraine’s acting president on Wednesday conceded what had long been obvious: The government’s police and security officials had lost control in the areas surrounding the cities of Donetsk and Luhansk.
articles.abstract: Ukraine’s acting president on Wednesday conceded what had long been obvious: The government’s police and security officials had lost control in the areas surrounding the cities of Donetsk and Luhansk.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — It is by now a well-established pattern. Armed, masked men in their 20s to 40s storm a public building of high symbolic value in a city somewhere in eastern Ukraine, evict anyone still there, seize weapons and ammunition, throw up barricades and proclaim themselves the rulers of a “people’s republic.” It is not clear who is in charge or how the militias are organized.
articles.byline: By Alison Smale and Andrew Roth

articles.headline: Once More, Economy Exhibits Weakness
articles.snippet: The economy grew only 0.1 percent in the first quarter, hurt by harsh winter weather and slow gains in inventories after stockpiles grew robustly in the second half of 2013.
articles.abstract: The economy grew only 0.1 percent in the first quarter, hurt by harsh winter weather and slow gains in inventories after stockpiles grew robustly in the second half of 2013.
articles.lead_paragraph: As has happened so many times since the recovery began nearly five years ago, the economy turned in another disappointing quarterly performance, surprising even the most pessimistic observers as growth in the first three months of 2014 slowed to a near-standstill.

articles.headline: Stern Talk From Chief of F.C.C. on Open Net
articles.snippet: Tom Wheeler, the F.C.C. chairman, says there is a shortfall in adequate broadband competition.
articles.abstract: Tom Wheeler, the F.C.C. chairman, says there is a shortfall in adequate broadband competition.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Federal Communications Commission’s chairman delivered a tough message to cable and broadband executives Wednesday, saying a lack of competition in their industry has hurt consumers.
